problem.statementHtml: Construct a 95% HPD interval for the mean of a normal distribution with unknown mean and variance.
hints: Think about how to use the posterior distribution
Recall the properties of the normal distribution
Consider the relationship between HPD intervals and frequentist CIs
problem.solutionHtml:
To construct a 95% HPD interval, we need to find the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles of the posterior distribution.

We can do this using the inverse cumulative distribution function (CDF) of the normal distribution.

statementHtml: Construct a credible interval (CI) for the mean of a normal distribution using Bayesian inference.
hints: Start by specifying a prior distribution for the mean.
Use Bayes' theorem to update the prior with the likelihood.
Find the HPD interval that contains p% of the posterior density.
solutionHtml:
To construct a CI, we need to specify a prior distribution for the mean, μ.

Let's assume a normal distribution with mean 0 and variance 100, scaled by the standard deviation of our data.

We then update this prior with the likelihood using Bayes' theorem:

\[p(\mu | X) \propto p(X | \mu) \cdot p(\mu)\]

Next, we find the HPD interval that contains p% of the posterior density.

title: Credible Intervals
statementHtml: Find a 95% credible interval for the mean of a normal distribution with known variance \(\sigma^2\) and unknown mean \(\mu\), given a dataset of size n.",
hints: [ "Start by finding the posterior distribution of \(\mu\)", "Use the fact that the prior is conjugate to the likelihood", "The credible interval will be based on the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles of this distribution" ],
solutionHtml:
To find the posterior distribution, we can use Bayes' theorem:

\[ p(\mu | \mathbf{x}) = rac{p(\mathbf{x} | \mu) \cdot p(\mu)}{\int p(\mathbf{x} | \mu) \cdot p(\mu) d\mu }.\]

Since the prior is conjugate to the likelihood, we can use a normal distribution with mean \(0\) and variance \( rac{1}{k}\sigma^2\) as our prior.

The posterior distribution will also be normal, with mean:

\[ \mu_{post} = rac{\sum_{i=1}^{n} x_i}{n} + \left( rac{\sigma^2}{k} ight) \cdot rac{1}{\sigma^2 + rac{k}{n}}.\]

The 95% credible interval will be the 2.5th and 97.5th percentiles of this distribution.
